Fabricating highly dispersed and stable LaMnO3 perovskite oxide catalysts for selective aerobic oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid under solvent-free conditions Jiahe Shan Writing – original draft Investigation Xuemei Jing Investigation Chuchu Zhang Investigation Enxian Yuan Funding acquisition Guojun Shi Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou, Jiangsu Province 225002, People's Republic of China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University Yangzhou Jiangsu Province 225002 People's Republic of China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou 225002, Jiangsu Province, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Chlorination-hydrolysis of toluene or homogeneous Co/Mn/Br catalyzed liquid phase oxidation of toluene to produce benzoic acid suffers from product halogen-contamination, severe equipment corrosion, and costly wastewater treatment industrially. Direct selective oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid under non-homogeneous catalyst, molecular oxygen, and solvent-free conditions will make this transformation more efficient and environmentally friendly. In this work, LaMnO3 perovskite oxide catalysts were fabricated by sol-gel method followed by etching and heat treatment, and tested via selective aerobic oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid under solvent-free conditions. The etched LaMnO3 perovskite oxide catalyst possesses a good mesoporous structure, significantly increased specific surface area and pore volume, halved grain size, reduced reduction temperature, and increased density of Mn4 + ions and oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. Further heat treatment significantly improved the catalyst stability while sacrificing some textural properties. The LaMnO3 perovskite oxide catalyst fabricated under the best conditions achieved a toluene conversion of 24.8 % and a benzoic acid selectivity of 82.7 %, with stable structural properties and catalytic performance after multiple cycles of use. This study can provide beneficial exploration and thinking for the design of perovskite oxide catalysts and their application in selective toluene oxidation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Toluene Solvent-free oxidation Perovskite oxide catalyst Etching Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Benzoic acid is an important chemical intermediate, which can be used for the production of amides, esters, alcohols, etc [1]. Benzoic acid and its derivates are commonly used as food preservatives, and also as defoamers in crude oil extraction. Benzoic acid can also be applied in the synthesis of alkyd resins, polyesters, plasticizers, dyes, rubber activators, etc [2]. Currently, the industrial production of benzoic acid mainly adopts the chlorination-hydrolysis process of toluene. This process suffers from severe equipment corrosion, large amounts of wastewater containing chlorine, and chlorine-contamination in the product [3]. Liquid-phase air oxidation of toluene to produce benzoic acid utilizes acetic acid as a solvent and homogeneous Co/Mn/Br as catalyst, which also suffers from severe equipment corrosion, bromine contamination in the product, and complicated separation of homogeneous catalysts [4,5]. In view of this, the industry and academia have been continuously working on developing a green and efficient method for the liquid-phase oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid. Photocatalytic oxidation of toluene to value-added oxygen-containing compounds presents a high selectivity to the desired products under relatively milder conditions, and an enhanced activity and/or yield is being pursued [6,7]. The transformation from toluene to benzoic acid was probed via thermo-catalysis in the liquid phase using H2O2 as the oxidant, showing advantages such as low reaction temperature, easy catalyst recovery, and high selectivity for benzoic acid [8]. Hunaiti et al. [9] proposed a method for synthesizing CuFe2O4 magnetic nanoparticles using pomegranate leaf extracts, and realized a conversion of from toluene to benzoic acid up to 67 % using H₂O₂ as a oxidant at 60 ºC for 20 h under solvent-free conditions. V-Mo-Fe-O [10], Ag/ZrO [11], Cu-Cr/g-C3N4 [12], Fe(III)-PVPDVB [13] catalysts also have shown high activity and selectivity for the selective oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid [14–18]. Mohammadpour et al. [19] loaded VO2+on Fe3O4@SiO2, and the resulting catalyst possessed a toluene conversion of over 99 % using tert-butyl hydroperoxide as the oxidant at room temperature in H2O. In addition, vanadium-substituted mesoporous aluminum phosphate [20], Co-MOF-74@Mn-MOF-74 [21], CoOx/SiO2 [22], Au-Pd/Cr2O3 [23] all showed good results for the selective oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde/benzoic acid with O2 or tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as the oxidant. Most of the above methods were carried out in organic solvents, mainly using H2O2 or TBHP as the oxidant. Compared with solvent-free oxidation via molecular oxygen, these methods have a relatively low space-time yields and/or higher oxidant costs. Transition metal oxides are widely studied due to a low cost, strong resistance to poisoning, and high catalytic activity. Manganese, as a multi-valent active metal element, is often used as a component of heterogeneous catalysts for the oxidation of organic compounds via molecular oxygen, and its oxides are also commonly used for the low-temperature oxidation of hydrocarbons. In the study by Li et al. [24], molecular oxygen was used as the oxidant to catalytically oxidize toluene using Mn3O4 in a solvent-free and additive-free system, the reaction was carried out at a pressure of 1.0 MPa and a temperature of 195 °C for 3 h, achieving a toluene conversion of 39 % and a selectivity to benzaldehyde of 93 %. Building on this, they prepared copper-manganese oxides through the co-precipitation method. The catalyst with a copper/manganese ratio of 1:1 exhibited a high activity in the selective oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde [25]. Jin et al. [26] synthesized octahedral MnO2 molecular sieves and found that the catalyst achieved a toluene conversion of 47.8 % and a selectivity to benzoic acid of 57 % at 110 °C under atmospheric reflux conditions for 20 h. Perovskite oxide catalysts as a potential alternative to precious metals have been extensively studied for their low cost, high chemical/thermal/structural stability, high oxidation activity, etc. Studies have been conducted on their application in CO oxidation [27], NOx reduction [28], oxidation of VOCs [29], sewage disposal [30], etc. Mistri et al. [31] synthesized copper-loaded LaMO3 (M=Mn, Fe, and Co) perovskites via a single-step solution combustion method, the conversion of and benzyl alcohol and the selectivity of benzaldehyde reached 98.7 % and 100 %, respectively, using TBHP as the oxidant at 80 °C under atmospheric pressure for 3 h. Perovskite oxides (ABO3) can be enhanced in terms of specific surface area and catalytic performance through acid etching [32]. During the etching process, the A-site cations is selectively removed from the perovskite structure, leading to the generation of more defects in the oxide, a higher specific surface area, abundant active oxygen, and oxygen vacancies. Meanwhile, the loss of A-site cations in the perovskite structure increases the valence state of the B-site cations. Chen et al. [33] successfully synthesized M nO x / LaMnO 3 catalysts for methane combustion via a selective etching method. They found that the modified LaMnO3 catalysts had a large specific surface area, a high Mn4+/(Mn4++Mn3+) molar ratio, and good low-temperature reducibility. Zhao et al. [34] synthesized a high specific surface area La 0.8 Ce 0.2 MnO 3 +δ catalyst using a sol-gel method, and then selectively removed part of the La3+ ions from the lattice via acid etching. The etched catalyst exhibited excellent performance in the oxidation of CO and C3H8, with conversion of 90 % for CO and C3H8 at temperatures of 73 ℃ and 196 ℃, respectively. The stability of perovskite oxide has always been a focus of attention. Pathreeker et al. [35] found that in the oxidation process of CaMnO3, changes in crystal structure may occur due to the migration of calcium ions and the rearrangement of oxygen atoms, leading to the coexistence of various phases such as CaxMnO3 and MnO2. Li et al. [36] found that the thermal deactivation of MnOx is mainly caused by structural changes of MnOx, and the structural stability can be enhanced through thermal treatment at an elevated temperature. Yuasa et al. [37] found that the stability of carbon-supported perovskite oxide can be improved by partially substituting the cations at A- or B-site. For example, the enhanced stability of the catalyst was achieved by partially substitution of B-site of LaMnO3 for iron ions. In addition, the partial substitution of calcium elements at the A-site of LaMn0.6Fe0.4O3 improved the average valence state at the B-site, thereby enhancing the stability and oxygen reduction activity of carbon-supported perovskite oxide [38]. In this work, the performance of perovskite oxide is investigated via oxidation of toluene under solvent-free conditions by tuning crystal structure and surface properties. The catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability of the catalyst are enhanced through etching and thermal treatment, providing new insights for designing high-performance catalysts and developing a green and efficient solvent-free toluene oxidation route. Perovskite-type oxide LaMnO3 was prepared by sol-gel method and its textural properties were improved by etching to promote the exposure of active sites and the generation of more oxygen vacancies. The etched samples were subjected to heat treatment to enhance their stability under reaction conditions. This work systematically explores the influence of etching and heat treatment conditions on the catalytic activity and stability of LaMnO3, as well as the structure-activity relationship. The mechanism of toluene oxidation to benzaldehyde in this catalytic system was also proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts Synthesis of LaMnO3. Using the sol-gel method to synthesize LaMnO3 catalyst. Firstly, La(NO3)2•6H2O (0.015 mol) and Mn(NO3)2•4H2O (0.015 mol) were dissolved in deionized water (100 mL) to obtain a mixed solution. Then, citric acid with a molar ratio of 1:1 to the metal ions was added as a chelating agent, and stirred until complete dissolution. The mixed solution was stirred in an oil bath at 80 ℃ for more than 5 h until the solution gradually became viscous, eventually forming a stable viscous gel. The obtained gel was dried in an oven at 100 ℃ in static air for 12 h to remove excess water. The dried gel was ground into powder, calcined in a muffle furnace at 400 ℃ in static air, further heated to 750 ℃, and then naturally cooled to room temperature to obtain the LaMnO3 sample, referred to as LMO. Etching of catalyst. A certain amount of LaMnO3 powder was added to the HNO3 solution (0.5 mol/L). Let it stand at room temperature for 200 min, 210 min, 230 min, 250 min, and 280 min, respectively. The suspends were filtrated and washed by deionized water repeatedly until the filtrate is neutral. The resulting powder were dried in static air at 120 ℃ overnight, and is designated as LMO-NA-X, where X is the etching duration (minutes). Thermal treatment of catalysts. The acid-treated catalyst was calcined in a muffle furnace to investigate the effects of different temperatures (300 ℃, 400 ℃, 500 ℃, 600 ℃, 700 ℃) and durations (1 h, 3 h, 6 h, 12 h, 24 h, 48 h). The samples after thermal treatment were denoted as LMO-NA-X-A-B, where A and B represent the treatment temperature (℃) and duration (h), respectively. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The resulting catalysts and their precursor were detailedly characterized to discover their textural, structural, thermal, and reducible properties, etc., and the information is included in supplementary material. 2.3 Evaluation of catalyst activity Performance of catalysts was evaluated by selective oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid under solvent-free conditions. Toluene (94 mmol) and catalyst (0.2 g) were added to a 50 mL high-pressure reactor, which was then sealed. Prior to the reaction, 3 MPa of O2 (99.999 %) was introduced into the reactor to check the air tightness. After confirming good sealing, the reactors were purged 5 times with O2 at 3 MPa to remove any residual air. Catalytic tests were carried out at 170 ℃, 3 MPa O2, and vigorous magnetic stirring (1000 rpm) for 24 h. After the reaction, nitrobenzene (9.4 mmol) was added as an internal standard. The catalyst and reaction solution were separated by centrifugation, and the reaction liquid was qualitatively and quantitatively analyzed by a Shimadzu GC-2010 Pro AF gas chromatographer. The analyses were operated as follows: initial temperature of 80 ℃, retention time of 2.5 min, followed by an increase to 230 ℃ at a ramp of 40 ℃/min and held at this temperature for 7 min. Qualitative analysis was based on the retention time of standard substances. Quantitative analysis was carried out using normalization, and carbon balance was calculated using the nitrobenzene as internal standard. 2.4 Evaluation of catalyst reusability After the reaction, the catalyst is separated from the reaction solution by centrifugation, washed for 4 times with ethanol, and dried at 100°C in an oven for 12 h in static air. The recovered catalyst after drying is evaluated using the same method as the fresh catalyst described in 2.3. 3 Properties and performance of catalysts 3.1 Structural and texture properties The elemental composition of LaMnO3 (LMO) catalysts and samples after etching and thermal treatment was analyzed by ICP-OES, as shown in Table 1. The molar ratio of La to Mn in the LMO catalyst after etching decreased from 0.98 (LMO) to 0.35 (LMO-NA-230), indicating the in-situ selective etching of La ions in LaMnO3 by dilute nitric acid. The La/Mn ratio of the calcined catalyst (LMO-NA-230–500–24) was 0.32, indicating a negligible change compared to before calcination. Fig. 1A shows the spectra of LaMnO3 (LMO) and its etched sample LMO-NA-230. It can be found that the diffraction peaks of LMO are consistent with the standard LaMnO3 spectrum (JCPDS 54–1275), indicating that the perovskite structure of LaMnO3 is well constructed. The sample etched with 0.5 mol/L HNO3 for 230 min still maintains the perovskite-dominant structure. The intensity of the diffraction peaks of LMO-NA-230 is slightly weaker compared to before etching. Meanwhile, weak diffraction peaks belonging to orthorhombic phase MnO2 appear at 45.1° and 61.7° (JCPDS 44–0142). The crystal grain sizes of LMO and LMO-NA-230 catalysts were calculated using the Scherrer equation, with the results shown in Table 1. The crystal grain size of LMO is ca. 40.5 nm, while the crystal grain size of the etched catalyst LMO-NA-230 was decreased to 20.4 nm, indicating that dilute nitric acid selectively removed La ions in LMO, reduced the grain size, and increased the surface area. This could provide more possible active sites for catalytic reactions. Considering the stability issue of perovskite oxide catalysts under reaction conditions, heat treatment was employed to improve their stability, as shown in Fig. 1B, The phase of the etched catalysts showed no significant change after heat treatment, with a slight increase in grain size, where the dXRD of LMO-NA-230–500–24 increased from 20.4 nm to 24.2 nm after heat treatment. This could be attributed to the movement of metal ions and oxygen ions in the lattice under thermal treatment conditions, leading to the merging of adjacent small grains into larger ones and thus the growth of grain size. The characteristic diffraction peaks of MnO2 disappeared after heat treatment, possibly existing highly dispersed on the surface of LaMnO3 and not being detected. Furthermore, the catalystLMO-NA-230 was thermally treated at different temperatures for 24 h, and the resulting catalysts presented pure phase of LaMnO3 (Figure S1). Stronger characteristic diffraction peaks were observed at an elevated treatment temperature, suggesting a possible agglomeration of grains. Fig. 2 shows the N2 physical adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of LMO and its modified catalysts. According to the IUPAC classification, all samples exhibit similar type IV isotherms and H3 hysteresis loops (Fig. 2A). The pre-etched LMO catalyst shows weak adsorption capacity and hysteresis loop, which may be due to the presence of a small number of pores formed by accumulation of particles. After etching treatment, both the adsorption capacity and hysteresis loop are significantly enhanced, forming obvious mesoporous structures. The specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of the catalysts LMO, LMO-NA-230, and LMO-NA-230–500–24 are listed in Table 1. It can be seen that the etching increased the specific surface area of the catalyst from 13.3 m2/g to 140 m2/g. Although there is not much change in pore diameter after etching, the pore volume was increased significantly (Fig. 2B). The main reason for the significant increase in specific surface area and pore volume may be related to the formation of more mesoporous structures after partial etching of La elements in the catalyst. The increased specific surface area and pore volume are not only beneficial for toluene to enter the interior of the catalyst, but also increases the contact between the catalyst and toluene. The increased specific surface area and pore structure may facilitate catalytic activity by providing more active sites and mass transfer channels. In addition, the pore diameters of the catalysts were also calculated according to a cylindrical mode and the resulting values are compared with experimental ones. The theoretical values are smaller than those obtained via N2 adsorption, which can be ascribed to their slit pore structure according to H3 hysteresis loops. After further heat treatment, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreased from 140 m2/g to 62.1 m2/g, but significantly higher than the unetched LMO catalyst. There was no significant change in pore volume observed after the heat treatment, but the average pore diameter increased by ca. 2 times. The pore size distribution of the catalyst narrowed after heat treatment, which is beneficial for maintaining the structural stability of the catalyst. The thermal treatment may induce phase transformation and structural adjustment in the crystal lattice, promoting pore expansion. Additionally, the post-etching LaMnO3 particles exhibit elevated surface energy, driving sintering-induced agglomeration during heat treatment. Smaller particles coalesce through fusion while pores merge, collectively manifesting as increased specific surface area and enlarged average pore diameter. Fig. 3 shows the scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of LMO, LMO-NA-230, and LMO-NA-230-500-24. The LMO sample exhibits an irregular shape with a size of approximately 30−50 nm. After etching in dilute HNO3 for 230 min, the originally smooth surface of LMO becomes rough. The La ions at site A were selectively removed and Mn ions were enriched on the catalyst surface, exposing more active sites. These changes collectively lead to an increase in the specific surface area, enhancing the possibility of toluene molecules contacting the catalyst surface. Fig. 4 shows the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy image of LMO-NA-230–500–24. The catalyst exhibits a uniform distribution of irregular particles and a porous microstructure, which should be related to the etching. From Fig. 4B, the obvious lattice structure on the surface of LMO-NA-230–500–24 is observed, consistent with its XRD pattern (Fig. 1). The lattice spacing of the sample after etching and heat treatment is mainly 0.256 nm and 0.286 nm, corresponding to the (204) and (212) crystal planes of LaMnO3. In Fig. 4B, disordered and blurry lattice stripes can also be observed, which may be attributed to the position of defects. These defects can be related to oxygen vacancies, which play an important role in the catalytic oxidation of toluene. The polycrystalline nature of the catalyst is also revealed by the corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern, consistent with XRD pattern of the catalyst. Additionally, the EDS element mapping of LMO-NA-230–500–24 shows a highly dispersed state of La, Mn, and O components in the sample, indicating a consistent pure phase structure of the LMO-NA-230-500-24 catalyst. 3.2 Redox properties and dispersity H2-TPR is used to analyze the redox properties of the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 5A. The H2 consumptions are quantitatively compared by integration of their H2-TPR profiles ( Table 2). There are two reduction peaks at 343 °C and 706 °C for the pristine LMO sample, probably corresponding to the reduction processes of Mn4+ to Mn3+ and Mn3+ to Mn2+ [39−42], respectively. The etched LMO-NA-230 catalyst presented hydrogen consumption at 190 °C, 343 °C and 696 °C, indicating more hydrogenation and lowered reduction temperature. This suggests that the LMO sample is easier to be reduced after etching. This enhancement in the redox properties of manganese species in the etched catalyst would be beneficial for the oxidation of toluene. Compared to the etched catalyst, the catalyst after heat treatment exhibited a decreases in hydrogenation consumption and an increase in reduction temperatures. This may be related to the agglomeration of grains, phase transformation and structural adjustment caused by the heat treatment (Table 1, Figs. 1, 2) [43,44]. Fig. 5B shows the oxygen desorption abilities of different catalysts. Three main oxygen desorption regions were observed for all LMO catalysts. The oxygen desorbed in the first region, within the range of 150−350 ℃, can be attributed to surface oxygen desorption. The oxygen desorbed in the second region, within the range of 350−550 ℃, can be assigned to oxygen vacancy desorption. The desorption range of the third region, in the range of 550−900 ℃, can be related to lattice oxygen desorption [45]. Considering that oxygen vacancies are the sites of oxygen activation, effects of etching and heat treatment on catalysts were investigated by integrating the desorption peak areas. As shown in Table 3, LMO-NA-230 exhibits the largest peak area at 350−550 ℃, indicating that it has the most oxygen vacancies, i.e., etching promotes the generation of oxygen vacancies, enhancing the migration of lattice oxygen. Further thermal treatment may reduce some surface adsorption sites, making the adsorption of surface oxygen molecules more difficult and requiring higher temperatures for desorption. 3.3 Chemical states of the elements Surface atomic concentration and chemical states of all LMO catalysts before and after etching and heat treatment were analyzed by XPS and shown in Fig. 6. As shown in Fig. 6A, two main asymmetric peaks were observed in all LMO samples, attributed to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 [46,47]. Deconvolution revealed peaks of Mn4+ and Mn3+, with the corresponding area ratios listed in Table 4. The ratios of Mn4+/(Mn4++Mn3+) for the catalysts LMO, LMO-NA-230-500-24, and LMO-NA-230-500-24-R6 were 5.09 %, 12.5 %, and 7.18 %, respectively. It can be seen that the generation of MnO2 on the surface of LMO after etching and heat treatment promoted the formation of surface Mn4+, consistent with the results of H2-TPR. The ratio of the Mn4+/(Mn4++Mn3+) of the recovered catalyst was observed a decrease. As shown in Fig. 6B, the core-level XP spectra of LMO, LMO-NA-230–500–24 and LMO-NA-230–500–24-R6, two peaks can correspond to the chemisorbed oxygen (Oads) and lattice oxygen (Olat) on the surface [48,49]. Oxygen vacancy is important for perovskite oxides, and its generation is calculated by the ratio of Oads/(Olat+Oads), which reflects the percentage of lattice oxygen converted to oxygen vacancies (Table 4). During the nitric acid etching of perovskite oxide LaMnO₃ (LMO), the strongly oxidative nitric acid oxidizes Mn³ ⁺ to Mn⁴⁺. To maintain charge balance, oxygen ions escape as molecular oxygen, creating oxygen vacancies in the LaMnO₃ catalyst. Additionally, hydrogen ions from nitric acid ionization induce lattice distortion through cation exchange in LMO, while structural degradation caused by etching weakens metal-oxygen chemical bonds. Both mechanisms destabilize oxygen ions, promoting their release and oxygen vacancy formation [50,51]. It can be seen that after etching and calcination, the binding energy of chemisorbed oxygen (Oads) and lattice oxygen (Olat) on LMO decreased by approximately 0.4 eV, possibly due to the selective etching of La ions. The Oads/(Olat+Oads) ratio increased from 17.2 % to 39.4 % after etching-heat treatment, indicating that etching can increase the oxygen vacancies density of the catalyst. The Oads/(Olat+Oads) ratio of the recovered catalyst's oxygen elements remained relatively stable after catalytic test, indicating the relative stability of the catalyst fabricated. 3.4 Catalytic performance of toluene selective oxidation 3.4.1 The effects of preparation conditions on the oxidation of toluene Table 5 shows the catalytic performance of LaMnO3 (LMO) and LMO-NA-X prepared at different etching durations for the solvent-free oxidation of toluene in the liquid phase. In the absence of catalyst, the conversion of toluene was only 4.09 %, with benzoic acid as the predominant product. This indicates that toluene autoxidation needs to overcome a high activation energy and thus present a low reactivity in the absence of catalyst. When LaMnO3 catalyst was introduced, the toluene conversion and the selectivity to benzoic acid reached 15.1 % and 80.4 %, respectively, indicating that the perovskite oxide LaMnO3 is an active catalyst for the solvent-free aerobic oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid in liquid phase. To further improve the catalytic performance of LaMnO3, etching with HNO3 was performed. The etching treatment exposes more active sites on the surface of LaMnO3, which is beneficial for oxygen adsorption and activation, thereby enhancing the catalytic ability of the catalyst. With the extension of etching duration, the catalytic activity reached its maximum value at 230 min, with a toluene conversion of 29.6 % and benzoic acid as the major product. This may be attributed to the acid-etched catalyst having a larger specific surface area and more mesoporous structures, increasing the contact opportunities with reactants and improving catalytic performance. Additionally, the oxygen vacancy density of the etched catalyst significantly increased, promoting toluene activation and selective conversion to benzoic acid. Further prolonging the etching time led to a decrease in catalyst activity. When the etching time was extended to 280 min, the toluene conversion of LMO-NA-280 was only 10.6 %, even lower than that of the pristine LMO catalyst, possibly due to excessive etching causing loss of surface active sites and a decrease in catalyst activity. As shown in Fig. 1A, trace MnO2 species were formed on the perovskite oxide LaMnO3 after acid etching. To assess the contribution of MnO2 species to toluene oxidation, Table S1 compares the toluene selective oxidation activity between hydrothermally synthesized MnO2 and the acid-etched catalyst LMO-NA-230. Pure MnO2 exhibited significantly lower activity than the LMO-NA-230 catalyst. This indicates that although trace MnO2 species were generated during acid etching of LMO-NA-230, they are not responsible for the enhanced catalytic performance. The effects of heat treatment temperature and time on the stability of the catalyst were investigated. After heat treatment at different temperatures, the LMO-NA-230 catalyst still retained the perovskite phase of LaMnO3 oxide, but upon catalyst recovery after the reaction, it was found that the catalyst underwent different degrees of phase transformation ( Fig. 7). A comparison of the heating temperatures revealed that the catalyst treated at 500 ℃ for 24 h exhibited the main phase of LaMnO3 (JCPDS 54-1275), but characteristic diffraction peaks belonging to Mn2O3 (JCPDS 41-1442) were still observed at 2θ of 38.5°, 45.1°, 49.3°, 55.1°, 65.8°, which was superior to catalysts thermally treated at other temperatures. The catalytic activity of LMO-NA-230–500–24 was the highest, with a conversion rate of 24.8 % and selectivity for benzoic acid of 82.7 % ( Table 6). Compared with those reports, the perovskite oxide catalysts fabricated in this work exhibited an excellent activity of toluene oxidation and a high selectivity to the desired benzoic acid via molecular oxygen under solvent-free conditions (Table S2). As shown in Fig. 7A, the catalyst treated at 400 ℃ for 24 h after etching exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks of MnO2 (JCPDS 30–0820), with weak characteristic peak of perovskite LaMnO3 at 32.4°, and the toluene conversion rate was decreased to 18.3 %. With the increase in thermal treatment temperature, the catalyst thermally treated at 600 ℃ exhibited a transformation from LaMnO3 into Mn2O3 after the catalytic test. The catalyst baked at 700 ℃ further oxidized the phase into Mn3O4 (JCPDS 24–0734), with a toluene conversion lower than 20 %. In order to find the optimal preparation conditions for the catalyst, the influence of thermal treatment time on the solvent-free oxidation of toluene was further investigated. Table 7 shows the effect of heat treatment time on the catalytic performance of the LMO-NA-230 catalyst. It was found that at a calcination temperature of 500 ℃, the conversion gradually decreased with an increasing duration. From Fig. 7B, it was found that when the calcination time was short, the recovered catalyst could not maintain the perovskite phase and completely transformed into the Mn2O3 (JCPDS 41–1442) phase. When the calcination time was 12 h, the recovered catalyst showed diffraction peaks of LaMnO3 (JCPDS 54-1275). Only after calcination at 500 ℃ for 24 h, although the Mn2O3 phase still existed, the main phase of the recovered catalyst was LaMnO3, with a conversion rate of 24.8 % and a selectivity to benzoic acid of 82.7 %. However, prolonging the calcination time did not further improve the purity of the catalyst phase, and the catalytic performance continued to decrease, with the conversion of LMO-NA-230–500–48 decreasing to 20.6 %. This may be due to prolonged heat treatment causing catalyst sintering, resulting in decreased catalytic activity. The nitric acid etching alters the surface structure and chemical composition of perovskite oxide LaMnO₃, inducing partial La leaching and possible valence state changes of Mn, generating abundant oxygen vacancies and unstable manganese oxide species. These modifications could destabilize the post-etched catalyst under reaction conditions. In LaMnO₃, manganese exhibits multiple valence states, with its distribution potentially varying across catalysts due to different calcination temperatures and heat treatment durations. These metastable species may evolve toward thermodynamically stable phases under reaction conditions. 3.4.2 Influence of reaction conditions on the oxidation of toluene Influence of reaction temperature on the solvent-free oxidation of toluene was investigated and the results are shown in Table 8, The conversion of toluene and the selectivity to benzoic acid are 10.7 % and 80.5 %, respectively, at 150 ℃. When the reaction temperature was increased to 170 ℃, the conversion of toluene increased to 24.8 % and the selectivity to benzoic acid also increased to 82.7 %. However, as the reaction temperature rose to 180 ℃, the increase in the conversion of toluene is relatively slow, only increasing from 24.8 % to 25.7 % with a similar selectivity to benzoic acid. Table 9 shows effect of reaction pressure on the catalytic activity of the LMO-NA-230-500-24 catalyst. In the case of 1 MPa O2, the conversion of toluene and the selectivity to benzoic acid are 12.8 % and 75.6 %, respectively. As the oxygen pressure was increased to 2 MPa, the conversion of toluene significantly increased to 19.4 %. With a further increase in pressure to 2.5 MPa, the conversion of toluene continued to increase to 22.9 %. When the pressure was further increased to 3 MPa, the conversion reached 24.8 % with a selectivity to benzoic acid of 82.7 %. It can be seen that when the oxygen pressure is low, a low solubility of oxygen resulted insufficient contact between oxygen and the substrate molecule toluene. Thus, the transformation from toluene to benzoic acid was predominated by the diffusion and mass transfer of oxygen molecules, rendering a low reactivity of toluene. Enhanced oxygen pressure increases the amount of the concentration of oxygen molecules in the reaction solution and significantly weakened or remove the impact of oxygen molecule diffusion on the oxidation of toluene and thus enhanced the reactivity of toluene. Table 10 explores the effect of reaction time on the catalytic performance of LMO-NA-230-500-24 catalyst. Toluene showed a very low reactivity at the beginning (entry 1). The conversion of toluene increases to 2.74 % in 3 h (entry 2). When the reaction time was 24 h, the conversion of toluene increased to 24.8 %, and the selectivity of benzoic acid also increased to 82.7 %. Continuing to extend the reaction time, the conversion of toluene and the selectivity of benzoic acid did not present an apparent increase, possibly due to the gradual decrease in the concentration of toluene as the reaction progresses. It can be observed that the time curve for solvent-free oxidation of toluene is an S-shaped curve, indicating a typical characteristic of auto-oxidation reaction (Figure S2). Effect of stirring speed on the solvent-free oxidation of toluene was investigated, as shown in Table 11. When the rotation speed of magneton was in the range of 200−1000 r/min, the conversion of toluene increased with the increase of rotation speed, rising from 11.5 % to 24.8 %, while there was little change in the range of 1000−1200 r/min. This indicates that within the range of 1000−1200 r/min rotation speed, the influence of external diffusion can be excluded in the early stages of the reaction, and toluene oxidation is governed by chemical reaction [52]. Increasing the stirring speed can enhance the mixing effect of the reaction system, allowing oxygen to more fully contact with toluene molecules, thereby removing the restriction from of the diffusion molecular oxygen. The influence of catalyst dosage on the catalytic performance of toluene was finally investigated, as shown in Table 12. When the mass of catalyst LMO-NA-230–500–24 was 0.1 g, the conversion of toluene was 9.78 % and the selectivity to benzoic acid was 77.4 %. With the gradual increase of catalyst mass, the conversion rate of toluene showed an increasing trend, reaching 15.1 %, 24.8 %, and 25.9 %. It can be found that when the mass of toluene increased to 0.25 g, the conversion of toluene did not further improve. This indicates that the catalytic reaction activity of LMO-NA-230-500-24 is related to the amount of catalyst. When the amount of catalyst is too low, a low reactivity of toluene can be ascribed to insufficient active sites that catalyst provides. However, a superfluous amount of catalyst may result in a decrease of contact between the toluene and active sites of catalyst due to the increase of the concentration of solid particles and apparent viscosity. In consideration of the effects of oxygen pressure (Table 9) and stirring rate (Table 11), the catalyst dosage is roughly linearly related to the conversion of toluene before its critical value, indicating that the initial oxidation rate is controlled by the chemical reaction rather than diffusion mass transfer (Figure S3) [53]. 3.4.3 Reusability of catalysts LMO-NA-230–500–24 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the solvent-free aerobic oxidation of toluene in a high-pressure reactor. Under the same experimental conditions, the activity stability of the LMO-NA-230–500–24 catalyst was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 8A, during the 6 cycles of the cycling test, both the toluene conversion rate (24.8 %) and the selectivity towards benzoic acid (82.7 %) of LMO-NA-230-500-24 remained relatively stable. Fig. 8B shows the XRD pattern of the fresh and the spent catalyst LMO-NA-230–500–24. Although there were some characteristic diffraction peaks of Mn2O3, the main phase of LMO-NA-230-500-24-R6 was LaMnO3 still. This indicates that the crystalline structure of the catalyst remained relatively stable after 6 cycles of catalytic performance evaluation, demonstrating good activity stability and recyclability of the catalyst treated at 500 ℃. 4 Reaction mechanism The product obtained is used as the raw material and catalytically oxidized under the same reaction conditions as toluene, with the results shown in Table 13. When benzaldehyde is used as the reactant, the conversion was as high as 97.4 %, with the main product being benzoic acid, indicating that benzaldehyde is easily oxidized to generate benzoic acid. When benzyl alcohol is used as the starting material, the conversion rate is 64.1 %, with a higher selectivity for benzaldehyde at 66.3 % and less selectivity for benzoic acid, indicating that the presence of benzyl alcohol may inhibit the over-oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid. When benzoic acid and benzyl benzoate are evaluated, both show low reaction activities. Accordingly, a reaction network of toluene under the reaction conditions is shown in Scheme 1. By adding the radical scavenger 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine oxide (TEMPO), it was found that the conversion rate of toluene (Entry 7) was significantly lower than the value without TEMPO (Entry 6), possessing a nearly same conversion to the blank experiment (Entry 5), indicating that the reaction may follow a radical mechanism [54]. Based on the XP spectra of the catalyst surface Mn4+ and Mn3+ after six catalytic cycles of LMO-NA-230–500–24, it was suggested that both stable Mn4+ and Mn3+ are beneficial for the oxidation reaction of toluene under solvent-free conditions. On the basis of catalytic test data and our previous work, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed, as shown in Eqs. 1−19 [55,56]. First, Mn3+ formed Mn4+ complex with surface oxygen (Eq. 1). This complex can abstract H atoms of the C−H bond of the toluene side chain, generating benzyl radical and metal peroxide and trigging the chain reaction (Eq. 2). Benzyl radical combined with a lone pair electron of O2 to form benzyl peroxyl radical (Eq. 3). The benzyl peroxyl radical grabbed a hydrogen atom from the starting material to produce benzyl hydroperoxide and benzyl radical (Eq. 4). According to Table 13, under suitable oxidation conditions with catalyst LMO-NA-230–500–24, benzyl hydroperoxide can be transformed into benzaldehyde and water (Eq. 5). Subsequently, the Mn4+ complex captured a hydrogen atom on the benzaldehyde side chain, generating a carbonyl radical and metal peroxide (Eq. 6). (1) LnMn III + O 2 → LnMn IV OO ⋅ (2) Image 1 (3) Image 2 (4) Image 3 (5) Image 4 (6) Image 5 Metal peroxide easily undergoes O−O bond cleavage under the action of metal ions, producing a strongly oxidizing metal intermediate and hydroxyl radical (Eq. 7). The carbonyl radical can react not only with the hydroxyl radical to produce benzoic acid (Eq. 8), but also with O2 to generate phenyl acyl peroxo radical (Eq. 9). The phenyl acyl peroxo radical captures of the H atoms the C−H bond of the toluene side chain, producing phenylperoxy acid and benzyl radical (Eq. 10). Phenylperoxy acid is activated under reaction conditions, leading to the cleavage of the peroxide bond and generating benzoylperoxy radical and hydroxyl radical (Eq. 11). The benzoylperoxy radical then generates benzoic acid and benzyl radical by abstracting a hydrogen atom from toluene (Eq. 12). (7) LnMn IV OOH → LnMn IV O ⋅ + ⋅ OH (8) Image 6 (9) Image 7 (10) Image 8 (11) Image 9 (12) Image 10 The benzyl radical reacts with the hydroxyl radical from the above reactions through radical coupling to produce benzyl alcohol (Eq. 13). The metal intermediate reacts with benzyl alcohol to produce metal hydroxide and benzyl radical (Eq. 14). The benzyl radical reacts with the hydroxyl radical through radical coupling to produce benzyl hydroperoxide (Eq. 15). Benzyl hydroperoxide can undergo intramolecular dehydration under reaction conditions to produce benzaldehyde (Eq. 5). The metal intermediate reacts with toluene to produce metal hydroxide and benzyl radical (Eq. 16). Under reaction conditions, the metal-hydroxide bond undergoes heterolytic cleavage, the metal ion gains electrons and is reduced to a lower oxidation state, and the O−H bond of the hydroxide ion cleaves, forming a hydroxyl radical (Eq. 17). Under strong basic conditions, benzaldehyde undergoes a Cannizzaro reaction, where two molecules of benzaldehyde interact, with one molecule being oxidized to produce benzoic acid, and the other molecule being reduced to produce benzyl alcohol (Eq. 18). Benzyl alcohol reacts with benzoic acid under reaction conditions to produce benzyl benzoate (Eq. 19), and the reaction terminates. (13) Image 11 (14) Image 12 (15) Image 13 (16) Image 14 (17) LnMn IV OH → LnMn III + ⋅ OH (18) Image 15 (19) Image 16 5 Conclusions This work focuses the fabrication and performance of perovskite oxide catalysts for the liquid-phase selective oxidation of toluene. The LaMnO3 perovskite oxide catalyst prepared by sol-gel method was etched to increase the density of active sites, and then heat-treated to improve stability. It was found that etching selectively removes some La ions, leading to significant enhancement in the specific surface area and pore volume. The catalyst prepared by etching LaMnO3 with 0.5 mol/L HNO3 for 230 min showed the highest activity under applied experimental conditions; further heat treatment at 500 ℃ for 24 h improved the stability of its structure and activity. Under optimized reaction conditions, the conversion of toluene and the selectivity to benzoic acid can reach 24.8 % and 82.7 %, respectively, with reliable stability. This can be attributed to its excellent textural properties, abundant surface oxygen concentration, and good low-temperature reducibility. It is suggested that LaMnO3 prepared by etching and heat treatment may be a potential low-cost, highly active, and stable method for the solvent-free aerobic oxidation of toluene. coredata.dc:description: Chlorination-hydrolysis of toluene or homogeneous Co/Mn/Br catalyzed liquid phase oxidation of toluene to produce benzoic acid suffers from product halogen-contamination, severe equipment corrosion, and costly wastewater treatment industrially. Direct selective oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid under non-homogeneous catalyst, molecular oxygen, and solvent-free conditions will make this transformation more efficient and environmentally friendly. In this work, LaMnO3 perovskite oxide catalysts were fabricated by sol-gel method followed by etching and heat treatment, and tested via selective aerobic oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid under solvent-free conditions. The etched LaMnO3 perovskite oxide catalyst possesses a good mesoporous structure, significantly increased specific surface area and pore volume, halved grain size, reduced reduction temperature, and increased density of Mn4 + ions and oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. Further heat treatment significantly improved the catalyst stability while sacrificing some textural properties. The LaMnO3 perovskite oxide catalyst fabricated under the best conditions achieved a toluene conversion of 24.8 % and a benzoic acid selectivity of 82.7 %, with stable structural properties and catalytic performance after multiple cycles of use. This study can provide beneficial exploration and thinking for the design of perovskite oxide catalysts and their application in selective toluene oxidation.
